text: ATTENTION! DON'T ASSEMBLE THE RESISTORS IN ANY H-BRIDGES! THERE IS A PROBLEM. :fire::huh-brandon::rage::sob:

elements.text: ATTENTION! DON'T ASSEMBLE THE RESISTORS IN ANY H-BRIDGES! THERE IS A PROBLEM.

text: what is the problem?

elements.text: what is the problem?

text: Okay, explanation forthcoming in a couple minutes.

elements.text: Okay, explanation forthcoming in a couple minutes.

text:
Here's the deal. It turns out that the pins on the ATSAMD21 processor on the MKR 1010 can run in two modes. In high drive strength mode, they can supply 7 mA. In low drive strength mode, they can supply only 2 mA. Unfortunately, it appears that 2 mA is the default, even though the Arduino documentation claims each pin can supply 7 mA and makes no mention of the drive strength setting.

If people's H-bridges use 1k resistors for the N-channel pulldowns and the current-limiter on the BJTs, they will draw more than 2 mA from a pin. The output voltage will sag, and the N-channels and BJTs might not turn on.

There is a software workaround, in which we use high drive strength mode, but it would be better to just fix the hardware. If we use 10k resistors for all positions on the H-bridge, the circuit draws less than 1 mA, and the problem is solved.

So, if anyone tries to get H-bridges assembled, please don't install 1k resistors. I'm going to send this out to the class, so everyone should understand the situation soon, but you guys are the last line of defense.

elements.text:
Here's the deal. It turns out that the pins on the ATSAMD21 processor on the MKR 1010 can run in two modes. In high drive strength mode, they can supply 7 mA. In low drive strength mode, they can supply only 2 mA. Unfortunately, it appears that 2 mA is the default, even though the Arduino documentation claims each pin can supply 7 mA and makes no mention of the drive strength setting.

If people's H-bridges use 1k resistors for the N-channel pulldowns and the current-limiter on the BJTs, they will draw more than 2 mA from a pin. The output voltage will sag, and the N-channels and BJTs might not turn on.

There is a software workaround, in which we use high drive strength mode, but it would be better to just fix the hardware. If we use 10k resistors for all positions on the H-bridge, the circuit draws less than 1 mA, and the problem is solved.

So, if anyone tries to get H-bridges assembled, please don't install 1k resistors. I'm going to send this out to the class, so everyone should understand the situation soon, but you guys are the last line of defense.

text: <@UV0AV32DQ> <@UUX9LS8AW> I am having trouble placing the ends of the wires that were soldered onto my buttons into my breadboard. I was wondering if there is any chance I could get thicker wire soldered onto them? Or get jumper cables soldered on?

elements.text: I am having trouble placing the ends of the wires that were soldered onto my buttons into my breadboard. I was wondering if there is any chance I could get thicker wire soldered onto them? Or get jumper cables soldered on?

text: If you bring them back to Nolop, someone can try to add some solder on the ends to thicken them a bit and make them stiffer
